"[588-the prince] " Advantage ? "[588-the prince] " [[Your]588-the prince Highness]3263-your highness , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan , " [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt is near to [Strasbourg]32-strasbourg , which again is not far from [Innspruck]17-innspruck , and being in [French territory]3300-french territory would be [the most convenient place to set off from]3301-the most convenient place to set off from . "[109-wogan] There was a sound of a door shutting ; [the Prince]588-the prince started , looked at [Wogan]109-wogan , and laughed . [He]588-the prince had been upon the verge of yielding ; but for that door [Wogan]109-wogan felt sure [he]109-wogan would have yielded . Now , however , [he]109-wogan merely walked away to [the Countess of [Berg]25-berg]598-the countess of berg , and sitting beside [her]598-the countess of berg asked [her]598-the countess of berg to play a particular tune . But [he]109-wogan still held the slip of paper in [his]109-wogan hand and paid but a scanty heed to the music , now and then looking doubtfully towards [Wogan]109-wogan , now and then scanning that long list of names . [His]109-wogan lips , too , moved as though [he]109-wogan was framing the three selected names , [Gaydon]142-gaydon , [Misset]143-misset , O'Toole , and " [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt "[109-wogan] as a bracket uniting [them]657-them . Then [he]109-wogan suddenly rose up and crossed [the room]317-the room to [Wogan]109-wogan . " [[My]109-wogan daughter]3254-my daughter wrote that [a woman]234-a woman must attend [her]3254-my daughter . It is a necessary provision . "[109-wogan] " [[Your]109-wogan Highness]3263-your highness , [Misset]143-misset has [a wife]3121-a wife , and [the wife]3306-the wife matches [him]109-wogan . "[109-wogan] " [They]657-them are warned to be ready ? "[109-wogan] " At [your]109-wogan Highness 's first word that slip of paper travels to [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt . It is unsigned , it imperils [no one]356-no one , it betrays nothing . But it will tell its story none the less surely to [those three men]3308-those three men , for [Gaydon]142-gaydon knows [my]109-wogan hand . "[109-wogan] [The Prince]588-the prince smiled in approval . " [You]588-the prince have prudence , [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner , as well as audacity , "[588-the prince] said [he]588-the prince . [He]588-the prince gave the paper back , listened for a little to [the Countess]599-the countess , who was bending over [her]599-the countess harp - strings , and then remarked , " [The Prince]588-the prince 's letter was in [his]588-the prince own hand too ? "[599-the countess] " But in cipher . "[588-the prince] " Ah ! "[588-the prince] [The Prince]588-the prince was silent for a while . [He]588-the prince balanced [himself]588-the prince first on one foot , then on the other . " Ciphers , "[588-the prince] said [he]588-the prince , " are curious things , compelling to the imagination and a provocation to the intellect . "[588-the prince] [Mr. Wogan]109-wogan kept a grave face and [he]109-wogan replied with unconcern , though [his]109-wogan heart beat quick ; for if [the Prince]588-the prince had so much desire to see [the Chevalier]348-the chevalier 's letter , [he]588-the prince must be well upon [his]588-the prince way to consenting to [Wogan]109-wogan 's plan . " If [[your]588-the prince Highness]3263-your highness will do [me]588-the prince the honour to look at this cipher . It has baffled [the most expert]3311-the most expert . "[588-the prince] [[His]588-the prince Highness]664-his highness condescended to be pleased with [Wogan]109-wogan 's suggestion . [Wogan]109-wogan crossed [the room]317-the room towards the door ; but before [he]109-wogan reached it , [the Countess of [Berg]25-berg]598-the countess of berg suddenly took [her]598-the countess of berg fingers from [her]598-the countess of berg harp - strings with a gesture of annoyance . " [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner , "[598-the countess of berg] [she]598-the countess of berg said , " will [you]130-mr. warner do [me]598-the countess of berg the favour to screw this wire tighter ? "[598-the countess of berg] And once or twice [she]598-the countess of berg struck it with [her]598-the countess of berg fingers . " May [I]588-the prince claim that privilege ? "[588-the prince] said [the Prince]588-the prince . " [[Your]588-the prince Highness]3263-your highness does [me]599-the countess too much honour , "[599-the countess] said [the Countess]599-the countess , but [the Prince]588-the prince was already at [her]599-the countess side . At once [she]598-the countess of berg pointed out to [him]588-the prince the particular string . [Wogan]109-wogan went from [the room]317-the room and up the great staircase . [He]109-wogan was lodged in [a wing of [the palace]629-the palace]671-a wing of the palace . From the head of [the staircase]673-the staircase [he]109-wogan proceeded down [a long passage]674-a long passage . Towards the end of [this passage another short passage]675-this passage another short passage branched off at a right angle on the left - hand side . At the corner of [the two passages]676-the two passages stood a table with a lamp and some candlesticks . This time [Wogan]109-wogan took a candle , and lighting it at the lamp turned into [the short passage]677-the short passage . [It]678-it was dark but for the light of [Wogan]109-wogan 's candle , and at the end of [it]678-it facing [him]109-wogan were two doors side by side . Both doors were closed , and of these [the one on the left]679-the one on the left gave onto [[his]109-wogan room]563-his room . [Wogan]109-wogan had walked perhaps halfway from the corner to [his]109-wogan door before [he]109-wogan stopped . [He]109-wogan stopped suddenly and held [his]109-wogan breath . Then [he]109-wogan shaded [his]109-wogan candle with the palm of [his]109-wogan hand and looked forward . Immediately [he]109-wogan turned , and walking on tiptoe came silently back into [the big passage]681-the big passage . Even this was not well lighted ; [it]681-the big passage stretched away upon [his]109-wogan right and left , full of shadows . But it was silent . The only sounds which reached [Wogan]109-wogan as [he]109-wogan stood there and listened were the sounds of [people moving and speaking at a great distance]682-people moving and speaking at a great distance . [He]109-wogan blew out [his]109-wogan candle , cautiously replaced it on the table , and crept down again towards [[his]109-wogan room]563-his room . There was no window in [this small passage]684-this small passage , there was no light there at all except a gleam of silver in front of [him]109-wogan and close to the ground . That gleam of silver was the moonlight shining between the bottom of one of the doors and the boards of [the passage]497-the passage . And that door was not the door of [[Wogan]109-wogan 's room]686-wogan 's room , but [the room beside [it]686-wogan 's room]687-the room beside it . Where [his]109-wogan door stood , there might have been no door at all . Yet the moon which shone through the windows of [one room]688-one room must needs also shine into the other , unless , indeed , the curtains were drawn . But earlier in the evening [Wogan]109-wogan had read a letter by the moonlight at [his]109-wogan window ; the curtains were not drawn . There was , therefore , a rug , an obstruction of some sort against the bottom of the door . But earlier in the evening [Wogan]109-wogan 's foot had slipped upon the polished boards ; there had been no mat or skin at all . It had been pushed there since . [Wogan]109-wogan could not doubt for what reason . It was to conceal the light of a lamp or candle within [the room]317-the room . [Someone]690-someone , in a word , was prying in [[Wogan]109-wogan 's room]686-wogan 's room , and [Wogan]109-wogan began to consider who . It was not [the Countess]599-the countess , who was engaged upon [her]599-the countess harp , but [the Countess]599-the countess had tried to detain [him]109-wogan . [Wogan]109-wogan was startled as [he]109-wogan understood the reason of [her]599-the countess harp becoming so suddenly untuned . [She]599-the countess had spoken to [him]109-wogan with so natural a spontaneity , [she]599-the countess had accepted [the Prince]588-the prince 's aid with so complete an absence of embarrassment ; but none the less [Wogan]109-wogan was sure that [she]599-the countess knew . Moreover , a door had shut — yes , while [he]109-wogan was speaking to [the Prince]588-the prince a door had shut . So far [Wogan]109-wogan 's speculations had travelled when the moonlight streamed out beneath [his]109-wogan door too . It made now a silver line across [the passage]497-the passage broken at the middle by the wall between [the rooms]697-the rooms . The mat had been removed , the candle put out , the prying was at an end ; in another moment the door would surely open . Now [Wogan]109-wogan , however anxious to discover who it was that spied , was yet more anxious that [the spy]698-the spy should not discover that the spying was detected . [He]109-wogan [himself]109-wogan knew , and so was armed ; [he]109-wogan did not wish to arm [[his]109-wogan enemies]699-his enemies with a like knowledge . There was no corner in [the passage]497-the passage to conceal [him]109-wogan ; there was no other door behind which [he]109-wogan could slip . When [the spy]698-the spy came out , [Wogan]109-wogan would inevitably be discovered . [He]109-wogan made up [his]109-wogan mind on the instant . [He]109-wogan crept back quickly and silently out of the mouth of [the passage]497-the passage , then [he]109-wogan made a noise with [his]109-wogan feet , turned again into [the passage]497-the passage , and walked loudly towards [his]109-wogan door . Even so [he]109-wogan was only just in time . Had [he]109-wogan waited a moment longer , [he]109-wogan would have been detected . For even as [he]109-wogan turned the corner there was already a vertical line of silver on the passage wall ; the door had been already opened . But as [his]109-wogan footsteps sounded on the boards , that line disappeared . [He]109-wogan walked slowly , giving [[his]109-wogan spy]704-his spy time to replace the letter , time to hide . [He]109-wogan purposely carried no candle , [he]109-wogan reached [his]109-wogan door and opened it . [The room to all seeming]705-the room to all seeming was empty . [Wogan]109-wogan crossed to a table , looking neither to the right nor the left , above all not looking towards the bed hangings . [He]109-wogan found the letter upon the table just as [he]109-wogan had left it . It could convey no knowledge of [his]109-wogan mission , [he]109-wogan was sure . It had not even the appearance of a letter in cipher ; it might have been a mere expression of Christmas good wishes from [one friend]706-one friend to another . But to make [his]109-wogan certainty more sure , and at the same time to show that [he]109-wogan had no suspicion [anyone]322-anyone was hiding in [the room]317-the room , [he]109-wogan carried the letter over to the window , and at once [he]109-wogan was aware of [the spy]698-the spy 's hiding - place . It was not the bed hangings , but close at [his]109-wogan side the heavy window curtain bulged . [The spy]698-the spy was at [his]109-wogan very elbow ; [he]109-wogan had but to lift [his]109-wogan arm — and of a sudden the letter slipped from [his]109-wogan hand to the floor . [He]109-wogan did not drop it on purpose , [he]109-wogan was fairly surprised ; for looking down to read the letter [he]109-wogan had seen protruding from the curtain a jewelled shoe buckle , and the foot which the buckle adorned seemed too small and slender for [a man]235-a man 's . [Wogan]109-wogan had an opportunity to make certain . [He]109-wogan knelt down and picked up the letter ; the foot was [a woman]234-a woman 's . As [he]109-wogan rose up again , the curtain ever so slightly stirred . [Wogan]109-wogan pretended to have remarked nothing ; [he]109-wogan stood easily by the window with [his]109-wogan eyes upon [his]109-wogan letter and [his]109-wogan mind busy with guessing what woman [[his]109-wogan spy]704-his spy might be . And [he]109-wogan remained on purpose for some while in this attitude , designing it as a punishment . So long as [he]109-wogan stood by the window that [unknown woman]714-unknown woman cheek by jowl with [him]109-wogan must hold [her]714-unknown woman breath , must never stir , must silently endure an agony of fear at each movement that [he]109-wogan made . At last [he]109-wogan moved , and as [he]109-wogan turned away [he]109-wogan saw something so unexpected that it startled [him]109-wogan . Indeed , for the moment it did more than startle [him]109-wogan , it chilled [him]109-wogan . [He]109-wogan understood that slight stirring of the curtain . [The woman]308-the woman now held a dagger in [her]308-the woman hand , and the point of the blade stuck out and shone in the moonlight like a flame . [Wogan]109-wogan became angry . It was all very well for [the woman]308-the woman to come spying into [[his]109-wogan room]563-his room ; but to take a dagger to [him]109-wogan , to think a dagger in [a woman]234-a woman 's hand could cope with [him,—that]719-him,—that was too preposterous . [Wogan]109-wogan felt very much inclined to sweep that curtain aside and tell [[his]109-wogan visitor]720-his visitor how [he]109-wogan had escaped from [Newgate]21-newgate and played hide - and - seek amongst the chimney - pots . And although [he]109-wogan restrained [himself]109-wogan from that , [he]109-wogan allowed [his]109-wogan anger to get the better of [his]109-wogan prudence . Under the impulse of [his]109-wogan anger [he]109-wogan acted . It was a whimsical thing that [he]109-wogan did , and though [he]109-wogan suffered for it [he]109-wogan could never afterwards bring [himself]109-wogan to regret it . [He]109-wogan deliberately knelt down and kissed the instep of the foot which protruded from the curtain . [He]109-wogan felt the muscles of the foot tighten , but the foot was not withdrawn . The curtain shivered and shook , but no cry came from behind it , and again the curtain hung motionless . [Wogan]109-wogan went out of [the room]317-the room and carried the letter to [the Prince]588-the prince . [The Countess of [Berg]25-berg]598-the countess of berg was still playing upon [her]598-the countess of berg harp , and [she]598-the countess of berg gave no sign that [she]598-the countess of berg remarked [his]109-wogan entrance . [She]598-the countess of berg did not so much as shoot one glance of curiosity towards [him]109-wogan . [The Prince]588-the prince carried the letter off to [[his]588-the prince cabinet]725-his cabinet , while [Wogan]109-wogan sat down beside [the Countess]599-the countess and looked about [the room]317-the room . " [I]109-wogan have not seen [Lady Featherstone]134-lady featherstone this evening , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan . " Have [you]109-wogan not ? "[599-the countess] asked [the Countess]599-the countess , easily . " Not so much as [her]599-the countess foot , "[109-wogan] replied [Wogan]109-wogan . The conviction came upon [him]109-wogan suddenly . [Her]599-the countess hurried journey to [Bologna]1-bologna and [her]599-the countess presence at [Ohlau]12-ohlau were explained to [him]109-wogan now by [her]599-the countess absence from [the room]317-the room . [His]109-wogan own arrival at [Bologna]1-bologna had not remained so secret as [he]109-wogan had imagined . [The fragile and gossamer lady]730-the fragile and gossamer lady , too flowerlike for [the world]245-the world 's rough usage , was [the woman who had spied in [[his]109-wogan room]563-his room and who had possessed the courage to stand silent and motionless behind the curtain after [her]599-the countess presence there had been discovered]732-the woman who had spied in his room and who had possessed the courage to stand silent and motionless behind the curtain after her presence there had been discovered . [Wogan]109-wogan had a picture before [his]109-wogan eyes of the dagger [she]599-the countess had held . It was plain that [she]599-the countess would stop at nothing to hinder this marriage , to prevent the success of [his]109-wogan design ; and somehow the contrast between [her]599-the countess appearance and [her]599-the countess actions had something uncanny about it . [Wogan]109-wogan was inclined to shiver as [he]109-wogan sat chatting with [the Countess]599-the countess . [He]109-wogan was not reassured when [Lady Featherstone]134-lady featherstone boldly entered [the room]317-the room ; [she]599-the countess meant to face [him]109-wogan out . [He]109-wogan remarked , however , with a trifle of satisfaction that for the first time [she]599-the countess wore rouge upon [her]599-the countess cheeks . [Wogan]109-wogan , however , was not immediately benefited by [his]109-wogan discovery . [He]109-wogan knew that if a single whisper of it reached [the Prince]588-the prince 's ear there would be at once an end to [his]109-wogan small chances . [The old man]737-the old man would take alarm ; [he]737-the old man might punish [the offender]738-the offender , but [he]737-the old man would none the less surely refuse [his]737-the old man consent to [Wogan]109-wogan 's project . [Wogan]109-wogan must keep [his]109-wogan lips quite closed and let [[his]109-wogan antagonists]739-his antagonists do boldly what [they]739-his antagonists would . And that [they]739-his antagonists were active [he]109-wogan found a way to discover . [The Countess from this time]740-the countess from this time plied [him]109-wogan with kindness . [He]109-wogan must play cards with [her]740-the countess from this time and [Prince Constantine]138-constantine in the evening ; [he]109-wogan must take [his]109-wogan coffee in [[her]740-the countess from this time private apartments]741-her private apartments in the morning . So upon one of these occasions [he]109-wogan spoke of [his]109-wogan departure from [Ohlau]12-ohlau . " [I]109-wogan shall go by way of [Prague]34-prague ; "[109-wogan] and [he]109-wogan stopped in confusion and corrected [himself]109-wogan quickly . " At least , [I]109-wogan am not sure . There are other ways into [Italy]29-italy . "[109-wogan] [The Countess]599-the countess showed no more concern than [she]599-the countess had shown over [her]599-the countess harp - string . [She]599-the countess talked indifferently of other matters as though [she]599-the countess had barely heard [his]109-wogan remark ; but [she]599-the countess fell into the trap . [Wogan]109-wogan was aware that [the Governor of [Prague]34-prague]743-the governor of prague was [[her]599-the countess kinsman]744-her kinsman ; and that afternoon [he]109-wogan left [the castle]634-the castle alone , and taking [the road]228-the road to [Vienna]16-vienna , turned as soon as [he]109-wogan was out of sight and hurried round [the town]3115-the town until [he]109-wogan came out upon [the road to [Prague]34-prague]748-the road to prague . [He]109-wogan hid [himself]109-wogan behind a hedge a mile from [Ohlau]12-ohlau , and had not waited half an hour before [a man]235-a man came riding by in hot haste . [The man]365-the man wore [the Countess]599-the countess 's livery of green and scarlet ; [Wogan]109-wogan decided not to travel by way of [Prague]34-prague , and returned to [the castle]634-the castle content with [his]109-wogan afternoon 's work . [He]109-wogan had indeed more reason to be content with it than [he]109-wogan knew , for [he]109-wogan happened to have remarked [the servant]753-the servant 's face as well as [his]109-wogan livery , and so at a later time was able to recognise it again . [He]109-wogan had no longer any doubt that [a servant in the same livery]754-a servant in the same livery was well upon [his]109-wogan way to [Vienna]16-vienna . [The roads]286-the roads were bad , it was true , and the journey long ; but [Wogan]109-wogan had not [the Prince]588-the prince 's consent , and could not tell when [he]109-wogan would obtain it . [The servant]753-the servant might return with [the Emperor]3102-the emperor 's order for [his]109-wogan arrest before [he]109-wogan had obtained it . [Wogan]109-wogan was powerless . [He]109-wogan sent [his]109-wogan list of names to [Gaydon]142-gaydon in [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt , but that was the only precaution [he]109-wogan could take . The days passed ; [Wogan]109-wogan spent them in unavailing persuasions , and New Year 's Day came and found [him]109-wogan still at [Ohlau]12-ohlau and in a great agitation and distress . Upon that morning , however , while [he]109-wogan was dressing , there came a rap upon [his]109-wogan door , and when [he]109-wogan opened it [he]109-wogan saw [the Prince 's treasurer]759-the prince 's treasurer , [a foppish gentleman]760-a foppish gentleman , very dainty in [his]760-a foppish gentleman words . " [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner , "[761-the treasurer] said [the treasurer]761-the treasurer , " [[his]109-wogan Highness]664-his highness has hinted to [me]761-the treasurer [his]109-wogan desires ; [he]664-his highness has moulded them into the shape of a prayer or a request . "[761-the treasurer] " In a word , [he]664-his highness has bidden [you]761-the treasurer , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan . " Fie , [sir]3070-sir ! There 's a barbarous and improper word , an ill - sounding word ; upon [my]109-wogan honour , a word without dignity or merit and banishable from polite speech . [[His]109-wogan Highness]664-his highness did most prettily entreat [me]109-wogan with a fine gentleness of condescension befitting a Sunday or a New Year 's Day to bring and present and communicate from hand to hand a gift,—a most incomparable proper gift , the mirror and image of [his]109-wogan most incomparable proper friendship . "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan bowed , and requested [the treasurer]761-the treasurer to enter and be seated the while [he]109-wogan recovered [his]109-wogan breath . " Nay , [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner , [I]761-the treasurer must be concise , puritanical , and unadorned in [my]761-the treasurer language as any raw - head or bloody - bones . The cruel , irrevocable moments pass . [I]761-the treasurer could consume an hour , [sir]3070-sir , before [I]761-the treasurer touched as [I]761-the treasurer may say the hem of the reason of [my]761-the treasurer coming . "[761-the treasurer] " [Sir]3070-sir , [I]109-wogan do not doubt it , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan . " But [I]109-wogan will not hinder [you]3070-sir from forthwith immediately and at once incorporating with [your]3070-sir most particular and inestimable treasures this jewel , this turquoise of heaven 's own charming blue , encased and decorated with gold . "[109-wogan] [The treasurer]761-the treasurer drew the turquoise from [his]761-the treasurer pocket . It was of the size of an egg . [He]761-the treasurer placed it in [Wogan]109-wogan 's hand , who gently returned it . " [I]109-wogan can not take it , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan . " [Gemini]145-gemini ! "[761-the treasurer] cried [the treasurer]761-the treasurer . " But it is more than a turquoise , [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner . [Jewellers]3318-jewellers have delved in it . It has become subservient to [man]3319-man 's necessities . It is a snuff - box . "[761-the treasurer] " [I]761-the treasurer can not take it . "[761-the treasurer] " [[King John]146-king john of [Poland]9-poland]3320-king john of poland , [he]146-king john whom [the vulgar]3321-the vulgar call [Glorious John]147-glorious john , did rescue and enlarge [it]145-gemini from [its]145-gemini slavery to [the Grand Vizier of [Turkey]35-turkey at the great battle of [Vienna]16-vienna]3322-the grand vizier of turkey at the great battle of vienna . There is no other in [the world]245-the world — "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan cut [the treasurer]761-the treasurer short . " [You]109-wogan will take it again to [[his]130-mr. warner Highness]664-his highness . [You]109-wogan will express to [him]664-his highness [my]109-wogan gratitude for [his]664-his highness kindness , and [you]109-wogan will say furthermore these words : ' [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner can not carry back into [Italy]29-italy a present for [himself]130-mr. warner and a refusal for [[his]130-mr. warner Prince]3325-his prince . ' "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan spoke with so much dignity that [the treasurer]761-the treasurer had no words to answer [him]109-wogan . [He]109-wogan stood utterly bewildered ; [he]109-wogan stared at the jewel . " Here is [a quandary]3326-a quandary ! "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan exclaimed . " [I]109-wogan do declare every circumstance of [me]109-wogan trembles , "[109-wogan] and shaking [his]109-wogan head [he]109-wogan went away . But in a little [he]109-wogan came again . " [[His]130-mr. warner Highness]664-his highness distinguishes [you]109-wogan , [Mr. Warner]130-mr. warner , with imperishable honours . [[His]130-mr. warner Highness]664-his highness solicits [[your]109-wogan company]3329-your company to a solitary dinner . [You]109-wogan shall dine with [him]664-his highness alone . [His]664-his highness presence and unfettered conversation shall season [your]109-wogan soup and be the condiments of [your]109-wogan meat . "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan 's heart jumped . There could be only one reason for so unusual an invitation on such a day , and [he]109-wogan was not mistaken ; for as soon as [the Prince]588-the prince was served in [a little room]768-a little room , [he]109-wogan dismissed [the lackeys]769-the lackeys and presented again the turquoise snuff - box with [his]109-wogan own hands . " See , [Mr. Wogan]109-wogan , [your]109-wogan persuasions and [your]109-wogan conduct have gained [me]109-wogan over , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan . " [Your]109-wogan refusal of [this bagatelle]3330-this bagatelle assures [me]109-wogan of [your]109-wogan honour . [I]109-wogan trust [myself]109-wogan entirely to [your]109-wogan discretion ; [I]109-wogan confide [[my]109-wogan beloved daughter]3331-my beloved daughter to [your]109-wogan care . Take from [my]109-wogan hands the gift [you]109-wogan refused this morning , and be assured that [no prince]3332-no prince ever gave to [any man]3333-any man such full powers as [I]109-wogan will give to [you]109-wogan to - night . "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan 's gratitude wellnigh overcame [him]109-wogan . The thing that [he]109-wogan had worked for and almost despaired of had come to pass . For a while [he]109-wogan could not speak ; [he]109-wogan flung [himself]109-wogan upon [his]109-wogan knees and kissed [the Prince]588-the prince 's hand . That very night [he]109-wogan received the letter giving [him]109-wogan full powers , and the next morning [he]109-wogan drove off in a carriage of [[his]109-wogan Highness]664-his highness drawn by six Polish horses towards [the town of]772-the town of [Strahlen]36-strahlen on [the road to [Prague]34-prague]748-the road to prague . At [Strahlen]36-strahlen [he]109-wogan stayed a day , feigning a malady , and sent [the carriage]287-the carriage back . The following day , however , [he]109-wogan took horse , and riding along [by - roads]775-by - roads and [lanes]776-lanes avoided [Prague]34-prague and hurried towards [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt . [He]109-wogan rode watchfully , avoiding [towns]777-towns , and with an eye alert for [every passer - by]778-every passer - by . That [he]109-wogan was ahead of [any courier from [the Emperor at [Vienna]16-vienna]3127-the emperor at vienna]779-any courier from the emperor at vienna [he]109-wogan did not doubt , but , on the other hand , [the Countess of [Berg]25-berg]598-the countess of berg and [Lady Featherstone]134-lady featherstone had the advantage of [him]109-wogan by some four days . There would be no lack of money to hinder [him]109-wogan ; there would be no scruple as to the means . [Wogan]109-wogan remembered the moment in [[his]109-wogan bedroom]782-his bedroom when [he]109-wogan had seen the dagger bright in the moon 's rays . If [he]109-wogan could not be arrested , there were other ways to stop [him]109-wogan . Accidents may happen to [any man]3333-any man . However , [he]109-wogan rode unhindered with [the Prince]588-the prince 's commission safe against [his]109-wogan breast . [He]109-wogan felt the paper a hundred times a day to make sure that it was not stolen nor lost , nor reduced to powder by a miracle . Day by day [his]109-wogan fears diminished , since day by day [he]109-wogan drew a day 's journey nearer to [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt . The paper became a talisman in [his]109-wogan thoughts,—a thing endowed with magic properties to make [him]109-wogan invisible like the cloak or cap of the fairy tales . Those few lines in writing not a week back had seemed an unattainable prize , yet [he]109-wogan had them ; and so now [they]785-they promised [him]109-wogan that other unattainable thing , the enlargement of [the Princess]3107-the princess . It was in [his]109-wogan nature , too , to grow buoyant in proportion to the difficulties of [his]109-wogan task . [He]109-wogan rode forward , therefore , with a good heart , and one sombre evening of rain came to [[a village]787-a village some miles beyond [Augsburg]15-augsburg]788-a village some miles beyond augsburg . [The village]789-the village was [a straggling half - mile of [low cottages]791-low cottages , lost as [it]789-the village were on the level of [a wide plain]792-a wide plain]790-a straggling half - mile of low cottages , lost as it were on the level of a wide plain . Across [this plain]793-this plain , bare but for a few lines of poplars and stunted willow - trees , [Wogan]109-wogan had ridden all the afternoon ; and so little did [the thatched cottages]794-the thatched cottages break the monotony of [the plain]795-the plain 's appearance , that though [he]109-wogan had had [the village]789-the village within [his]109-wogan vision all that while , [he]109-wogan came upon [it]789-the village unawares . The dusk was gathering , and already through the tiny windows the meagre lights gleamed upon [the road]228-the road and gave to the falling raindrops the look of steel beads . Four days would now bring [Wogan]109-wogan to [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt . [The road]228-the road was bad and full of holes . [He]109-wogan determined to go no farther that night if [he]109-wogan could find [a lodging in [the village]789-the village]799-a lodging in the village , and coming upon [a man who stood in [his]109-wogan path]801-a man who stood in his path [he]109-wogan stopped [his]109-wogan horse . " Is there [an inn where [a traveller]3335-a traveller may sleep ? "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan asked]3334-an inn where a traveller may sleep ? " he asked . " Assuredly , "[365-the man] replied [the man]365-the man , " and find forage for [his]365-the man horse . "[365-the man] " There is no need , [[my]109-wogan friend]3085-my friend , that [you]3085-my friend should take a colic , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan . " [I]365-the man shall earn enough drink to correct the colic , "[365-the man] said [the man]365-the man . [He]109-wogan had a sack over [his]109-wogan head and shoulders to protect [him]109-wogan from the rain , and stepped out in front of [Wogan]109-wogan 's horse . [They]804-they came to the end of [the street]292-the street and passed on into the open darkness . About twenty yards farther [a house]3268-a house stood by [itself]3268-a house at the roadside , but there were only lights in one or two of the upper windows , and [it]3268-a house held out no promise of hospitality . In front of [it]3268-a house , however , [the man]365-the man stopped ; [he]365-the man opened the door and halloaed into [the passage]497-the passage . [Wogan]109-wogan stopped too , and above [his]109-wogan head something creaked and groaned like a gibbet in the wind . [He]109-wogan looked up and saw a sign - board glimmering in the dusk with a new coat of white paint . [He]365-the man had undoubtedly come to [the inn]231-the inn , and [he]365-the man dismounted . [The landlord]218-the landlord advanced at that moment to the door . " [[My]218-the landlord man]3338-my man , "[218-the landlord] said [he]218-the landlord , " will take [your]109-wogan horse to [the stable]3339-the stable ; "[218-the landlord] and [the fellow who had guided [Wogan]109-wogan]811-the fellow who had guided wogan led the horse off . " Oh , is [he]365-the man [[your]218-the landlord man]3340-your man ? "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan . " Ah ! "[109-wogan] And [he]109-wogan followed [the landlord]218-the landlord into [the house]3196-the house . It was not only the sign - board which had been newly painted , for in [the narrow passage]814-the narrow passage [the landlord]218-the landlord stopped [Wogan]109-wogan . " Have a care , [sir]3070-sir , "[218-the landlord] said [he]218-the landlord ; " the walls are wet . It will be best if [you]3070-sir stand still while [I]218-the landlord go forward and bring a light . "[218-the landlord] [He]218-the landlord went forward in the dark and opened a door at the end of [the passage]497-the passage . A glow of ruddy light came through the doorway , and [Wogan]109-wogan caught a glimpse of [a brick - floored kitchen]817-a brick - floored kitchen and a great open chimney and [one or two men]818-one or two men on a bench before the fire . Then the door was again closed . The closing of the door seemed to [Wogan]109-wogan a churlish act . " The hospitality , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan to [himself]109-wogan , " which plants [a man in [the road]228-the road]3342-a man in the road so that [a traveller]3335-a traveller on a rainy night may not miss [his]3335-a traveller bed should at least leave the kitchen door open . Why should [I]109-wogan stay here in the dark ? "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan went forward , and from the careful way in which [he]109-wogan walked,—a way so careful and stealthy indeed that [his]109-wogan footsteps made no sound,—it might have been inferred that [he]109-wogan believed the floor to be newly painted too . [He]109-wogan had , at all events , no such scruples about the kitchen door , for [he]109-wogan seized the handle and flung it open quickly . [He]109-wogan was met at once by a cold draught of wind . A door opposite and giving onto [a yard at the back]819-a yard at the back had been opened at precisely the same moment ; and as [Wogan]109-wogan stepped quickly in at [his]109-wogan door [a man]235-a man stepped quickly out by the door opposite and was lost in the darkness . " What ! Are [you]109-wogan going ? "[218-the landlord] [the landlord]218-the landlord cried after [him]109-wogan as [he]218-the landlord turned from the fire at which [he]218-the landlord was lighting a candle . " [You]109-wogan found [your]109-wogan way , [sir]3070-sir , "[218-the landlord] said [he]218-the landlord , looking at [Wogan]109-wogan anxiously . A great iron pot swung over the fire by a chain , and the lid danced on the top and allowed a savoury odour to escape . [Wogan]109-wogan sat [himself]109-wogan down before the fire and [his]109-wogan clothes began to steam . " [You]109-wogan laugh at [my]218-the landlord paint , but it is , after all , a very important thing . "[109-wogan] " It has a sign - board , but without a device , "[218-the landlord] said [the landlord]218-the landlord , and while [Wogan]109-wogan drew a chair to the table [he]109-wogan explained [his]109-wogan predicament . " There is [another inn five miles along [the road]228-the road]3360-another inn five miles along the road , and [travellers]3362-travellers prefer to make [their]3362-travellers halt [there]3363-there . [They]3362-travellers will not stop here . [[My]109-wogan father]3249-my father , [sir]3070-sir , set it all down to paint . ' [The Black Eagle]3369-the black eagle ' is [its]3196-the house old name . ' [You]3070-sir are travelling to [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt , perhaps . "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan had started ever so slightly . " [[My]109-wogan friend]3085-my friend , "[109-wogan] so [his]109-wogan thoughts ran , " the sooner [you]3085-my friend reach [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt the better .
