Then [he]737-the old man said timidly , " It was for [a woman]234-a woman , no doubt , that [you]1129-the count ran this hazard to - night ? "[737-the old man] " For [a woman]234-a woman , yes . "[1129-the count] [The Count]1129-the count folded [his]1129-the count hands and leaned forward . " [Sir]3070-sir , [a woman]234-a woman is a strange inexplicable thing to [me]1129-the count . [Their]234-a woman words , [their]234-a woman looks , [their]234-a woman graceful , delicate shapes , the motives which persuade [them]234-a woman , the thoughts which [their]234-a woman eyes conceal,—all these qualities make [them]234-a woman beings of another world to [me]1129-the count . [I]1129-the count do envy men at times who can stand beside [them]234-a woman , talk with [them]234-a woman without fear , be intimate with [them]234-a woman , and understand [their]234-a woman intricate thoughts . "[1129-the count] " Are there [such men]3494-such men ? "[109-wogan] asked [Wogan]109-wogan . " [Men who love , such as [Count Königsmarck]154-königsmarck and [yourself]1129-the count]3495-men who love , such as count königsmarck and yourself . "[109-wogan] [Wogan]109-wogan held up [his]109-wogan hand with a cry . " [Count]3496-count , [such men]3494-such men , [we]3498-we are told , are the blindest of all . Did not [Königsmarck]154-königsmarck prove it ? As for [myself]109-wogan , not even in that respect can [I]109-wogan be ranked with [Königsmarck]154-königsmarck . [I]109-wogan am [a mere man - at - arms , whose love - making is a clash of steel]3499-a mere man - at - arms , whose love - making is a clash of steel . "[109-wogan] " But to - night — this risk [you]109-wogan ran ; [you]109-wogan told [me]109-wogan it was for [a woman]234-a woman . "[109-wogan] " For [a woman]234-a woman , yes . For love of [a woman]234-a woman , no , no , no ! "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan exclaimed with surprising violence . Then [he]109-wogan rose from [his]109-wogan chair . " But [I]109-wogan have stayed [my]109-wogan time , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan , " [you]109-wogan have never had [a more grateful guest]3503-a more grateful guest . [I]109-wogan beg [you]109-wogan to believe it . "[109-wogan] [Count Otto]153-count otto barely heard the words . [He]153-count otto was absorbed in the fanciful dreams born of many long solitary evenings , and like [most timid and uncommunicative men]1150-most timid and uncommunicative men [he]153-count otto made [his]153-count otto confidence in a momentary enthusiasm to [a stranger]1151-a stranger . " [Königsmarck]154-königsmarck spoke for an hour , mentioning no names , so that [I]1152-i who from [my]1152-i youth have lived apart could not make a guess . [He]154-königsmarck spoke with a deal of passion ; it seemed that one hour [his]154-königsmarck life was paradise and the next a hell . Even as [he]154-königsmarck spoke [he]154-königsmarck was one instant all faith and the next all despair . One moment [he]154-königsmarck was filled with [his]154-königsmarck unworthiness and wonder that so noble a creature as [a woman]234-a woman should bend [her]234-a woman heart and lips from [her]234-a woman heaven down to [[his]154-königsmarck earth]3505-his earth . The next [he]154-königsmarck could not conceive [any man]3333-any man should be such a witless ass as to stake [his]154-königsmarck happiness on the steadiness of so manifest a weathercock as [a woman]234-a woman 's favour . It was all very strange talk ; it opened to [me]1152-i , just as when a fog lifts and rolls down again , a momentary vision of a world of colours in which [I]1152-i had no share ; and to tell the truth it left [me]1152-i with a suspicion which has recurred again and again , that all [my]1152-i solitary years over [my]1152-i books , all the delights which the delicate turning of a phrase , or the chase and capture of an elusive idea , can bring to one may not be worth , after all , one single minute of living passion . Passion , Chevalier ! There is a word of which [I]1152-i know the meaning only by hearsay . But [I]1152-i wonder at times , whatever harm it works , whether there can be any great thing without it . But [you]109-wogan are anxious to go forward upon [your]109-wogan way . "[1152-i] [He]1152-i again took up [his]1152-i lamp , and requesting [Wogan]109-wogan to follow [him]1152-i , unlatched the window . [Wogan]109-wogan , however , did not move . " [I]109-wogan am wondering , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan , " whether [I]109-wogan might be yet deeper in [your]109-wogan debt . [I]109-wogan left behind [me]109-wogan a sword . "[109-wogan] [Count Otto]153-count otto set [his]153-count otto lamp down and took a sword from the corner of [the room]317-the room . " [I]153-count otto called it an ornament , and yet in other hands it might well prove a serviceable weapon . The blade is of Spanish steel . [You]109-wogan will honour [me]153-count otto by wearing it . "[153-count otto] [Wogan]109-wogan was in two minds with regard to [the Count]1129-the count . On the one hand , [he]109-wogan was most grateful ; on the other [he]109-wogan could not but think that over [his]109-wogan books [he]109-wogan had fallen into a sickly way of thought . [He]109-wogan was quite ready , however , to wear [his]109-wogan sword ; moreover , when [he]109-wogan had hooked the hanger to [his]109-wogan belt [he]109-wogan looked about [the room]317-the room . " [I]109-wogan had a pistol , "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan said carelessly , " a very useful thing is a pistol , more useful at times than a sword . "[1129-the count] [Mr. Wogan]109-wogan was quite able to wait . [He]109-wogan was indeed sufficiently generous to tell [Count Otto]153-count otto that [he]109-wogan need not hurry . [The Count]1129-the count fetched the pistol and took up the lamp again . " Will [you]109-wogan now follow [me]1129-the count ? "[1129-the count] [Wogan]109-wogan looked straight before [him]109-wogan into the air and spoke to [no one in particular]1158-no one in particular . " A pistol is , to be sure , more useful than a sword ; but there is just one thing more useful on an occasion than a pistol , and that is a hunting knife . " Now , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan , pleasantly , " all that [I]109-wogan need is a sound , swift , thoroughbred horse about six or seven years old . "[109-wogan] And so [he]109-wogan rode off upon [his]109-wogan way . The morning was just beginning to gleam pale in [the east]1174-the east . [Here]3086-here was a night passed which [he]109-wogan had not thought to live through , and [he]109-wogan was still alive to help [the chosen woman imprisoned in [the hollow of the hills at [Innspruck]17-innspruck]1177-the hollow of the hills at innspruck]1176-the chosen woman imprisoned in the hollow of the hills at innspruck . [Wogan]109-wogan had reason to be grateful to [that old man who stood straining [his]109-wogan eyes after [him]109-wogan]1178-that old man who stood straining his eyes after him . There was something pathetical in [his]109-wogan discontent with [his]109-wogan secluded life which touched [Wogan]109-wogan to the heart . [Wogan]109-wogan was not sure that in the morning [the old man]737-the old man would know that the part [he]109-wogan had chosen was , after all , the best . Besides , [Wogan]109-wogan had between [his]109-wogan knees the most friendly and intelligent beast which [he]109-wogan had ridden since that morning when [he]109-wogan met [Lady Featherstone]134-lady featherstone on [the road to [Bologna]1-bologna]1180-the road to bologna . But [he]109-wogan had soon other matters to distract [his]109-wogan thoughts . However easily [Flavia]157-flavia cantered or trotted [she]157-flavia could not but sharply remind [him]109-wogan of [his]109-wogan wounds . [He]109-wogan had forty miles to travel before [he]109-wogan could reach [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt ; and in [the villages on [the road]228-the road]1181-the villages on the road there was gossip that day of [a man with a tormented face who rode rocking in [his]109-wogan saddle as though the furies were at [his]109-wogan back]1183-a man with a tormented face who rode rocking in his saddle as though the furies were at his back . [The little town of Schlestadt]1184-the little town of schlestadt went to bed betimes . By ten o'clock [its burghers]1185-its burghers were in [their]1185-its burghers night - caps . [A belated visitor]1186-a belated visitor going [home]1187-home at that hour found [his]109-wogan footsteps ring upon [the pavement]1188-the pavement with surprising echoes , and traversed [dark street]1189-dark street after [dark street]1189-dark street , seeing in each window , perhaps , a mimic moon , but no other light unless [his]109-wogan path chanced to lie through [Herzogstrasse]45-herzogstrasse . In [that street]1191-that street a couple of windows on the first floor showed bright and unabashed , and [the curious passer - by]1192-the curious passer - by could detect upon the blind the shadows of [men growing to monstrous giants]1193-men growing to monstrous giants and dwindling to pigmies according as [they]1193-men growing to monstrous giants approached or retired from the lamp in [the room]317-the room . There were [three men in [that room]335-that room]1195-three men in that room booted as for a journey . [Their]1195-three men in that room dress might have misled [one]3129-one into the belief that [they]1195-three men in that room were [merchants]1198-merchants , but [their]1195-three men in that room manner of wearing it proclaimed [them]1195-three men in that room [soldiers]1199-soldiers . Of [the three , one]1200-the three , one , [a short , spare man]1201-a short , spare man , sat at the table with [his]1201-a short , spare man head bent over a slip of paper . [His]1201-a short , spare man peruke was pushed back from [his]1201-a short , spare man forehead and showed that the hair about [his]1201-a short , spare man temples was grey . [He]1201-a short , spare man had a square face of some strength , and thoughtful eyes . [The second of the three]1202-the second of the three stood by the window . [He]1202-the second of the three was , perhaps , a few years younger , thirty - six [an observer]1203-an observer might have guessed to the other 's forty , and [his]1202-the second of the three face revealed a character quite different . [His]1202-the second of the three features were sharp , [his]1202-the second of the three eyes quick ; if prudence was the predominating quality of the first , resource took its place in the second . While [the first man]1204-the first man sat patiently at the table , [this one]1205-this one stood impatiently at the window . Now [he]1204-the first man lifted the blind , now [he]1204-the first man dropped it again . [The third]1206-the third sat in front of the fire with [his]1206-the third face upturned to the ceiling . [He]1206-the third puffed and breathed very heavily ; once or twice [he]1206-the third sighed , and at each sigh [his]1206-the third chair creaked under [him]1206-the third . "[142-gaydon] [Wogan]109-wogan sat before the fire without a word while [O'Toole]158-o'toole spread the table and set a couple of cold partridges upon it and a bottle of red wine . [Wogan]109-wogan ate mechanically for a little and afterwards with some enjoyment . [He]109-wogan picked the partridges till the bones were clean , and [he]109-wogan finished the bottle of wine . Then [he]109-wogan rose to [his]109-wogan feet with a sigh of something very like to contentment and felt along the mantel - shelf with [his]109-wogan hands . [O'Toole]158-o'toole , however , had foreseen [his]109-wogan wants and handed [him]109-wogan a pipe newly filled . "[142-gaydon] " Then it 's not a lottery , "[158-o'toole] murmured [O'Toole]158-o'toole , " and [we]3537-we 've drawn no prizes . "[158-o'toole] " Ah , but [we]3537-we are going to , "[109-wogan] cried [Wogan]109-wogan . " [We]3537-we are safe [here]3086-here . [No one]356-no one can hear [us]3537-we ; [no one]356-no one can burst in . But [I]109-wogan am sure of that . [Misset]143-misset knows the trick that will make [us]3537-we safe from interruption , eh ? "[109-wogan] [Misset]143-misset looked blankly at [Wogan]109-wogan . " Why , [one]3129-one can turn the key , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan . " To be sure , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan , with a laugh of admiration for that device of which [he]109-wogan had bethought [himself]109-wogan , and which [he]109-wogan ascribed to [Misset]143-misset , " if there 's a key ; but if there 's no key , why , a chair tilted against the door to catch the handle , eh ? "[109-wogan] [Misset]143-misset locked the door , not at all comprehending that device , and returned to [his]109-wogan seat . " [We]3537-we are to draw the greatest prize that ever was drawn , "[109-wogan] resumed [Wogan]109-wogan , and [he]109-wogan broke off . " But is there a cupboard in [the room]317-the room ? "[109-wogan] [Gaydon]142-gaydon jumped up from [his]142-gaydon chair . " But upon [my]142-gaydon word there is a cupboard , "[142-gaydon] [he]142-gaydon cried , and crossing to a corner of [the room]317-the room [he]142-gaydon opened a door and looked in . [Wogan]109-wogan laughed again as though [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's examination of the cupboard was a very good joke . " There will be [nobody]3545-nobody in [it]1241-the cupboard , "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan cried . " [Gaydon]142-gaydon will never feel a hand gripping the life out of [his]142-gaydon throat because [he]142-gaydon forgot to search a cupboard . "[109-wogan] [The cupboard]1241-the cupboard was empty , as it happened . " To be sure , [you]158-o'toole are [a great man]3392-a great man , [Charles]109-wogan . The most probable convincing story that was ever invented ! Oh ! but [you]158-o'toole 'll hear [Jenny]161-jenny sob with pity for [the heiress]3661-the heiress and [Lucius O'Toole]158-o'toole when [she]161-jenny hears it . It will be a bad day , too , for [the merciless parents]3662-the merciless parents when [they]3662-the merciless parents discover [Jenny]161-jenny in [[her]161-jenny Highness]3138-her highness 's bed . [She]161-jenny stands six feet in [her]161-jenny stockings . "[158-o'toole] " Six feet ! "[109-wogan] exclaimed [Wogan]109-wogan . " In [her]161-jenny stockings , "[109-wogan] returned [O'Toole]158-o'toole . " [Her]161-jenny height is [her]161-jenny one vanity . Therefore in [her]161-jenny shoes [she]161-jenny is six feet four . "[109-wogan] " Well , [she]161-jenny must take [her]161-jenny heels off and make [herself]161-jenny as short as [she]161-jenny can . "[158-o'toole] " [You]109-wogan will have trouble , [[my]158-o'toole friend]3085-my friend , to persuade [her]161-jenny to that , "[158-o'toole] said [O'Toole]158-o'toole . " Hush ! "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon . [He]142-gaydon rose and unlocked the door . [The doctor]1235-the doctor was knocking for admission below . [Gaydon]142-gaydon let [him]142-gaydon in , and [he]142-gaydon dressed [Wogan]109-wogan 's wounds with an assurance that they were not deep and that a few days ' quiet would restore [him]142-gaydon . " [I]109-wogan will sleep the night [here]3086-here if [I]109-wogan may , "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan , as soon as [the doctor]1235-the doctor had gone . " A blanket and a chair will serve [my]109-wogan turn . "[109-wogan] [They]1265-they took [him]142-gaydon into [[Gaydon]142-gaydon 's bedroom]1266-gaydon 's bedroom , where [three beds were ranged]1267-three beds were ranged . " [We]1265-they have slept in [the one room]3666-the one room and lived together since [your]109-wogan message came four days ago , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon . " Take [your]109-wogan choice of the beds , for there 's not one of [us]1265-they has so much need of a bed as [you]109-wogan . "[142-gaydon] [Wogan]109-wogan drew a long breath of relief . " Oh ! but it 's good to be with [you]142-gaydon , "[109-wogan] [he]109-wogan cried suddenly , and caught at [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's arm . " [I]109-wogan shall sleep to - night . How [I]109-wogan shall sleep ! "[109-wogan] [He]109-wogan stretched out [his]109-wogan aching limbs between the cool white sheets , and when the lamp was extinguished [he]109-wogan called to [each of [[his]109-wogan three friends]1269-his three friends]1268-each of his three friends by name to make sure of [their]1269-his three friends company . [O'Toole]158-o'toole answered with a grunt on [his]109-wogan right , [Misset]143-misset on [his]109-wogan left , and [Gaydon]142-gaydon from the corner of [the room]317-the room . " But [I]109-wogan have wanted [you]109-wogan these last three days ! "[109-wogan] said [Wogan]109-wogan . " To - morrow when [I]109-wogan tell [you]109-wogan the story of [them]1269-his three friends [you]109-wogan will know how much [I]109-wogan have wanted [you]109-wogan . "[109-wogan] [They]1269-his three friends got , however , some inkling of [Wogan]109-wogan 's need before the morrow came . In the middle of the night [they]1269-his three friends were wakened by a wild scream and heard [Wogan]109-wogan whispering in an agony for help . [They]1269-his three friends lighted a lamp and saw [him]109-wogan lying with [his]109-wogan hand upon [his]109-wogan throat and [his]109-wogan eyes starting from [his]109-wogan head with horror . " Quick , "[109-wogan] said [he]109-wogan , " the hand at [my]109-wogan throat ! It 's not the letter so much , it 's [my]109-wogan life [they]1269-his three friends want . "[109-wogan] " It 's [your]142-gaydon own hand , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon , and taking the hand [he]142-gaydon found it lifeless . [Wogan]109-wogan 's arm in that position had gone to sleep , as the saying is . [He]109-wogan had waked suddenly in the dark with the cold pressure at [his]109-wogan throat , and in the moment of waking was back again alone in [the inn near [Augsburg]15-augsburg]1271-the inn near augsburg . [Wogan]109-wogan indeed needed [[his]109-wogan friends]989-his friends . The next morning [Wogan]109-wogan was tossing from side to side in a high fever . The fever itself was of no great importance , but it had consequences of a world - wide influence , for it left [Wogan]109-wogan weak and tied to [his]109-wogan bed ; so that it was [Gaydon]142-gaydon who travelled to [Rome]4-rome and obtained [the Pope]3095-the pope 's passport . [Gaydon]142-gaydon consequently saw what otherwise [Wogan]109-wogan would have seen ; and [Gaydon]142-gaydon , [the cautious , prudent Gaydon]1274-the cautious , prudent gaydon , was careful to avoid making an inopportune discovery , whereas [Wogan]109-wogan would never have rested until [he]109-wogan had made it . [Gaydon]142-gaydon stayed in [Rome]4-rome a week , lying snug and close in a lodging only one street removed from [that house upon [the Tiber]49-the tiber where [[his]142-gaydon King]326-his king lived]1275-that house upon the tiber where his king lived . [Secrets]163-secrets had a way of leaking out , and [Gaydon]142-gaydon was determined that this one should not through any inattention of [his]142-gaydon . [He]142-gaydon therefore never went abroad until dark , and even then kept aloof from [the house which overlooked [the Tiber]49-the tiber]1277-the house which overlooked the tiber . [His]142-gaydon business [he]142-gaydon conducted through [[his]142-gaydon servant]312-his servant , sending [him]142-gaydon to and fro between [Edgar]121-edgar , [the secretary]412-the secretary , and [himself]142-gaydon . [One audience of [[his]142-gaydon King]326-his king]1280-one audience of his king alone [he]142-gaydon asked , and that was to be granted [him]142-gaydon on the day of [his]142-gaydon departure from [Rome]4-rome . Thus the time hung very heavily upon [him]142-gaydon . From daybreak to dusk [he]142-gaydon was cooped within [a little insignificant room]1282-a little insignificant room which looked out upon [a little insignificant street]1283-a little insignificant street . [His]142-gaydon window , however , though it promised little diversion , was [his]142-gaydon one resource . [Gaydon]142-gaydon was [a man of observation]1284-a man of observation , and found a pleasure in guessing at this and [that person]323-that person 's business from [his]142-gaydon appearance , [his]142-gaydon dress , and whether [he]142-gaydon went fast or slow . So [he]142-gaydon sat steadily at [his]142-gaydon window , and after a day or two had passed [he]142-gaydon began to be puzzled . The moment [he]142-gaydon was puzzled [he]142-gaydon became interested . On the second day [he]142-gaydon drew [his]142-gaydon chair a little distance back from the window and watched . On the third day [he]142-gaydon drew [his]142-gaydon chair close to the window , but at the side and against the wall . In this way [he]142-gaydon could see everything that happened and [everyone who passed]1286-everyone who passed , and yet remain [himself]142-gaydon unobserved . Almost opposite to [his]142-gaydon window stood [a small mean house]1287-a small mean house fallen into neglect and disrepair . The windows were curtained with dust , many of the panes were broken , the shutters hung upon broken hinges , the paint was peeling from the door . [The house]3196-the house had the most melancholy aspect of long disuse . [It]3196-the house seemed to belong to [no one]356-no one and to be crumbling pitifully to ruin like [an aged man who has [no friends]1291-no friends]1290-an aged man who has no friends . Yet [this house]1292-this house had [its]1292-this house uses , which [Gaydon]142-gaydon could not but perceive were of a secret kind . On the very first day that [Gaydon]142-gaydon sat at [his]142-gaydon window [a man]235-a man , who seemed from [his]235-a man [dress to be of a high consideration]1294-dress to be of a high consideration , came sauntering along [that sordid thoroughfare]1295-that sordid thoroughfare , where [he]235-a man seemed entirely out of place , like a butterfly on [the high seas]1296-the high seas . To [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's surprise [he]235-a man stopped at the door , gave a cautious look round , and rapped quickly with [his]235-a man stick . At once the door of [that uninhabited house]1297-that uninhabited house was opened . [The man]365-the man entered , the door was closed upon [him]365-the man , and a good hour by [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's watch elapsed before it was opened again to let [him]365-the man out . In the afternoon [another man]3607-another man came and was admitted with the same secrecy . [Both men]1077-both men had worn [their]1077-both men hats drawn down upon [their]1077-both men foreheads , and whereas one of [them]1077-both men held a muffler to [his]235-a man face , [the other]260-the other had thrust [his]260-the other chin within the folds of [his]260-the other cravat . [Gaydon]142-gaydon had not been able to see the face of either . After nightfall [he]142-gaydon remarked that such visits became more frequent . Moreover , they were repeated on the next day and the next . [Gaydon]142-gaydon watched , but never got any nearer to a solution of the mystery . At the end of the sixth day [he]142-gaydon was more puzzled and interested than ever , for closely as [he]142-gaydon had watched [he]142-gaydon had not seen the face of [any man who had passed in and out of that door]1302-any man who had passed in and out of that door . But [he]142-gaydon was to see a face that night . At nine o'clock [a messenger from [Edgar]121-edgar]1303-a messenger from edgar , [the secretary]412-the secretary , brought [him]142-gaydon a package which contained a letter and the passport for these six days delayed . The letter warned [him]142-gaydon that [Edgar]121-edgar [himself]121-edgar would come to fetch [him]142-gaydon in the morning to [[his]121-edgar audience]1305-his audience with [James]112-james stuart . The passport gave authority to [a Flemish nobleman , [the Count of [Cernes]50-cernes]1307-the count of cernes , to make a pilgrimage to [Loretto]46-loretto with [[his]1307-the count of cernes wife]589-his wife and [family]1309-family]1306-a flemish nobleman , the count of cernes , to make a pilgrimage to loretto with his wife and family . The name of [Warner]129-chevalier had served its turn and could no longer be employed . As soon as [the messenger]1310-the messenger had gone , [Gaydon]142-gaydon destroyed [Edgar]121-edgar 's letter , put the passport safely away in [his]142-gaydon breast , and since [he]142-gaydon had not left [[his]142-gaydon room]563-his room that day , put on [his]142-gaydon hat . Being [a prudent man with a turn for economy]1312-a prudent man with a turn for economy , [he]142-gaydon also extinguished [his]142-gaydon lamp . [He]142-gaydon had also a liking for fresh air , so [he]142-gaydon opened the window , and at the same moment the door of [the house]3196-the house opposite was opened . [A tall burly man with a lantern in [his]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand hand]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand stepped out into [the street]292-the street ; [he]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand was followed by [a slight man of a short stature]1316-a slight man of a short stature . [Both men]1077-both men were wrapped in [their]1077-both men cloaks , but [the shorter one]1318-the shorter one tripped on a break in [the road]228-the road and [his]1318-the shorter one cloak fell apart . [[His]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand companion]649-his companion turned at once and held [his]649-his companion lantern aloft . Just for a second the light therefore flashed upon a face , and [Gaydon]142-gaydon at [his]142-gaydon dark window caught a glimpse of it . The face was the face of [[his]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand King]326-his king . [Gaydon]142-gaydon was more than ever puzzled . [He]142-gaydon had only seen the face for an instant ; moreover , [he]142-gaydon was looking down upon it , so that [he]142-gaydon might be mistaken . [He]142-gaydon felt , however , that [he]142-gaydon was not , and [he]142-gaydon began to wonder at the business that could take [[his]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand King]326-his king to [this mysterious house]1323-this mysterious house . But there was one thing of which [he]142-gaydon was sure amidst all [his]142-gaydon doubts , [Rome]4-rome was not [the safest city in [the world]245-the world]1324-the safest city in the world for [a man]235-a man to walk about at nights . [[His]1314-a tall burly man with a lantern in his hand King]326-his king would be none the worse off for [a second guardian who would follow near enough to give help and far enough for discretion]1328-a second guardian who would follow near enough to give help and far enough for discretion . [Gaydon]142-gaydon went down [his]142-gaydon stairs into [the street]292-the street . The lantern twinkled ahead ; [Gaydon]142-gaydon followed [it]1330-it until [it]1330-it stopped before [a great house which had lights burning here and there in the windows]1331-a great house which had lights burning here and there in the windows . [The smaller man]1332-the smaller man mounted the steps and was admitted ; [[his]1332-the smaller man big companion with the lantern]1333-his big companion with the lantern remained outside . [Gaydon]142-gaydon , wishing to make sure of [his]142-gaydon conjectures one way or the other , walked quickly past [him]1332-the smaller man and stole a glance sideways at [his]1332-the smaller man face . But [the man with the lantern]1334-the man with the lantern looked at [Gaydon]142-gaydon at the same moment . [Their]1335-their eyes met , and the lantern was immediately held aloft . " It is [Major Gaydon]142-gaydon . "[142-gaydon] [Gaydon]142-gaydon had to make the best of the business . [He]142-gaydon bowed . " [Mr. Whittington]111-whittington , [I]142-gaydon think . "[142-gaydon] " [Sir]3070-sir , "[111-whittington] said [Whittington]111-whittington , politely , " [I]111-whittington am honoured by [your]3070-sir memory . [We]1335-their did meet , [I]111-whittington believe , in [Paris]51-paris ? [You]3070-sir are of [[Dillon]144-dillon 's regiment]3669-dillon 's regiment ? "[111-whittington] " And on leave in [Rome]4-rome , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon , a trifle hastily . " On leave ? "[111-whittington] said [Whittington]111-whittington , idly . " Well , so far as [towns]777-towns go , [Rome]4-rome is as good as another , though , to tell the truth , [I]111-whittington find [them]777-towns all quite unendurable . Would [I]111-whittington were on leave ! but [I]111-whittington am pinned [here]3086-here , [a watchman with a lantern]3672-a watchman with a lantern . "[142-gaydon] [He]142-gaydon had a thought that [the Chevalier]348-the chevalier , since [he]348-the chevalier would be secret , had chosen [[his]348-the chevalier watchman]1337-his watchman rather ill . [He]142-gaydon had no wish to pry , and so was for returning to [[his]142-gaydon lodging]373-his lodging ; but [that careless , imprudent man]1339-that careless , imprudent man , [Whittington]111-whittington , would not lose [a companion]1340-a companion so easily . [He]111-whittington caught [Gaydon]142-gaydon by the arm . " Well , it is [the house of [Maria Vittoria]164-maria vittoria]3675-the house of maria vittoria , [Mademoiselle de Caprara]165-mademoiselle de caprara , [the heiress of [Bologna]1-bologna , who has only this evening come to [Rome]4-rome]3676-the heiress of bologna , who has only this evening come to rome . "[111-whittington] " Hardly , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon , " since [I]142-gaydon leave [Rome]4-rome to - morrow . "[142-gaydon] " Indeed ? " [I]111-whittington would [I]111-whittington were as fortunate , "[111-whittington] and [he]111-whittington jerked [his]111-whittington thumb dolefully towards [the Caprara Palace]1341-the caprara palace . [Gaydon]142-gaydon hesitated for a moment , considering whether or not [he]142-gaydon should ask [Whittington]111-whittington to be silent upon [their]1342-their meeting . But [he]142-gaydon determined [the man]365-the man was too incautious in [his]365-the man speech . If [he]142-gaydon begged [him]111-whittington not to mention [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's presence in [Rome]4-rome , [he]111-whittington would remember it the more surely , and if nothing was said [he]111-whittington might forget it . [Gaydon]142-gaydon wished [him]111-whittington good - night and went back to [[his]142-gaydon lodging]373-his lodging , walking rather moodily . [Whittington]111-whittington looked after [him]142-gaydon and chuckled . Meanwhile , in [a room of [the house]3196-the house]1345-a room of the house [two people]1347-two people sat,—one [the slight , graceful man who had accompanied [Whittington]111-whittington and whom [Gaydon]142-gaydon had correctly guessed to be [[his]142-gaydon King]326-his king]1348-the slight , graceful man who had accompanied whittington and whom gaydon had correctly guessed to be his king , the other , [Maria Vittoria de Caprara]164-maria vittoria . [The Chevalier de St. George]114-the chevalier was speaking awkwardly with a voice which broke . [Maria]164-maria vittoria listened with a face set and drawn . [She]164-maria vittoria was [a girl both in features and complexion of a remarkable purity]1350-a girl both in features and complexion of a remarkable purity . Of colour , but for [her]164-maria vittoria red lips , [she]164-maria vittoria had none . [Her]164-maria vittoria hair was black , [her]164-maria vittoria face of a clear pallor which [her]164-maria vittoria hair made yet more pale . [Her]164-maria vittoria eyes matched [her]164-maria vittoria hair , and were so bright and quick a starry spark seemed to glow in the depths of them . [She]164-maria vittoria was [a poet]1351-a poet 's simile for night . [The Chevalier]348-the chevalier ended and sat with [his]348-the chevalier eyes turned away . [Maria Vittoria]164-maria vittoria did not change [her]164-maria vittoria attitude , nor for a while did [she]164-maria vittoria answer , but the tears gathered in [her]164-maria vittoria eyes and welled over . They ran down [her]164-maria vittoria cheeks ; [she]164-maria vittoria did not wipe them away , [she]164-maria vittoria did not sob , nor did [her]164-maria vittoria face alter from its fixity . [She]164-maria vittoria did not even close [her]164-maria vittoria eyes . Only the tears rained down so silently that [the Prince]588-the prince was not aware of them . [He]348-the chevalier had even a thought as [he]348-the chevalier sat with [his]348-the chevalier head averted that [she]164-maria vittoria might have shown a trifle more of distress , and it was almost with a reproach upon [his]348-the chevalier lips that [he]348-the chevalier turned to [her]164-maria vittoria . Never was [a man]235-a man more glad that [he]348-the chevalier had left a word unspoken . This silent grief of tears cut [him]348-the chevalier to the heart . " [Maria]164-maria vittoria ! "[348-the chevalier] [he]348-the chevalier cried , and moved towards [her]164-maria vittoria . [She]164-maria vittoria made no gesture to repel [him]348-the chevalier , [she]164-maria vittoria did not move , but [she]164-maria vittoria spoke in a whisper . " [[His]348-the chevalier Holiness [the Pope]3095-the pope]3682-his holiness the pope had consented to [our]3684-our marriage . What would [I]164-maria vittoria not have done for [you]164-maria vittoria ? "[164-maria vittoria] [The Chevalier]348-the chevalier stooped over [her]164-maria vittoria and took [her]164-maria vittoria hand . The hand remained inert in [his]348-the chevalier . " [Maria]164-maria vittoria ! "[348-the chevalier] " Would that [I]348-the chevalier were poor ! Would that [I]348-the chevalier were powerless ! But [I]348-the chevalier am rich — so rich . [I]348-the chevalier could have done so much . [I]348-the chevalier am alone — so much alone . What would [I]348-the chevalier not have done for [you]164-maria vittoria ? "[348-the chevalier] " [Maria]164-maria vittoria ! "[348-the chevalier] [His]348-the chevalier voice choked upon the word , [his]348-the chevalier lips touched [her]164-maria vittoria hair , and [she]164-maria vittoria shivered from head to foot . Then [her]164-maria vittoria hand tightened fast upon [his]348-the chevalier ; [she]164-maria vittoria drew [him]348-the chevalier down almost fiercely until [he]348-the chevalier sank upon [his]348-the chevalier knees by [her]164-maria vittoria side ; [she]164-maria vittoria put an arm about [his]348-the chevalier shoulder and held [him]348-the chevalier to [her]164-maria vittoria breast . " But [you]348-the chevalier love [me]164-maria vittoria , "[164-maria vittoria] [she]164-maria vittoria said quickly . " Tell [me]164-maria vittoria so ! Say , ' [I]164-maria vittoria love [you]348-the chevalier , [I]164-maria vittoria love [you]348-the chevalier , [I]164-maria vittoria love [you]348-the chevalier . ' Oh that [we]3685-we both could die , [you]348-the chevalier saying it , [I]164-maria vittoria hearing it,—die to - night , like this , [my]164-maria vittoria arm about [you]348-the chevalier , [your]348-the chevalier face against [my]164-maria vittoria heart ! [[My]164-maria vittoria lord]3686-my lord , [[my]164-maria vittoria lord]3686-my lord ! "[164-maria vittoria] and then [she]164-maria vittoria flung [him]1356-his from [her]164-maria vittoria , holding [him]1356-his at arm 's length . " Say it with [your]1356-his eyes on [mine]164-maria vittoria ! [I]164-maria vittoria can see though the tears fall . [I]164-maria vittoria shall never hear the words again after to - night . Do not stint [me]164-maria vittoria of them ; let them flow just as these tears flow . They will leave no more trace than do [my]164-maria vittoria tears . "[164-maria vittoria] " [Maria]164-maria vittoria , [I]348-the chevalier love [you]164-maria vittoria , "[348-the chevalier] said [the Chevalier]348-the chevalier . " How [I]348-the chevalier do love [you]164-maria vittoria ! "[348-the chevalier] [He]348-the chevalier took [her]164-maria vittoria hands from [his]1356-his shoulders and pressed [his]1356-his forehead upon them . [She]164-maria vittoria leaned forward , and in a voice so low it seemed [her]164-maria vittoria heart was whispering , not [her]164-maria vittoria mouth , [she]164-maria vittoria made [her]164-maria vittoria prayer . " Say that [you]1356-his have no room in [your]1356-his thoughts except for [me]164-maria vittoria . Say that [you]1356-his have no scrap of love — "[164-maria vittoria] [He]1356-his dropped [her]164-maria vittoria hands and drew away ; [she]164-maria vittoria caught [him]1356-his to [her]164-maria vittoria . " No , no ! Say that [you]1356-his have no scrap of love to toss to [the woman there]3688-the woman there in [Innspruck]17-innspruck ! "[164-maria vittoria] " [Maria]164-maria vittoria ! "[1356-his] [he]1356-his exclaimed . " Hush ! "[164-maria vittoria] said [she]164-maria vittoria , with a woful smile . " To - morrow [you]1356-his shall love [her]3688-the woman there ; to - morrow [I]164-maria vittoria will not ask [your]1356-his eyes to dwell on [mine]164-maria vittoria or [your]1356-his hand to quiver as it touches [mine]164-maria vittoria . But to - night love [no one]356-no one but [me]164-maria vittoria . "[164-maria vittoria] For answer [he]1356-his kissed [her]164-maria vittoria on the lips . [She]164-maria vittoria took [his]1356-his head between [her]164-maria vittoria hands and gave the kiss back , gently as though [her]164-maria vittoria lips feared to bruise [his]1356-his , slowly as though this one moment must content [her]164-maria vittoria for all [her]164-maria vittoria life . Then [she]164-maria vittoria looked at [him]1356-his for a little , and with a childish movement that was infinitely sad [she]164-maria vittoria laid [his]1356-his face side by side with [hers]164-maria vittoria so that [his]1356-his cheek touched [hers]164-maria vittoria . " Shall [I]164-maria vittoria tell [you]1356-his [my]164-maria vittoria thought ? "[164-maria vittoria] [she]164-maria vittoria asked . " Shall [I]164-maria vittoria dare to tell [you]1356-his it ? "[164-maria vittoria] " Tell it [me]164-maria vittoria ! "[164-maria vittoria] " [God]126-wogan has died to - night . Hush ! Do not move ! Do not speak ! Perhaps [the world]245-the world will slip and crumble if [we]1358-we but stay still . "[164-maria vittoria] And [they]1358-we remained thus cheek to cheek silent in [the room]317-the room , staring forward with eyes wide open and hopeful . The very air seemed to [them]1358-we a - quiver with expectation . [They]1358-we , too , had an expectant smile upon [their]1358-we lips . But there was no crack of thunder overhead , no roar of a slipping world . [The Chevalier]114-the chevalier was the first to move . " But [we]1358-we are [children]896-children , "[114-the chevalier] [he]114-the chevalier cried , starting up . " Is it not strange the very pain which tortures [us]1358-we because [we]1358-we are [man]3319-man and [woman]3693-woman should sink [us]1358-we into [children]896-children ? [We]1358-we sit hoping that a miracle will split [the world]245-the world in pieces ! This is [the Caprara Palace]1341-the caprara palace ; [Whittington]111-whittington drowses outside over [his]111-whittington lantern ; and to - morrow [Gaydon]142-gaydon rides with [his]142-gaydon passport northwards to [Charles Wogan]126-wogan . "[164-maria vittoria] At that all [Maria Vittoria]164-maria vittoria 's vehemence left [her]164-maria vittoria . [She]164-maria vittoria fell to beseechings and entreaties . [She]164-maria vittoria dropped upon [her]164-maria vittoria knees and dragged [herself]164-maria vittoria across [the room]317-the room to [him]1361-him . " [You]112-james stuart told [me]164-maria vittoria business would call [you]112-james stuart to [Spain]18-spain . Go [there]3363-there ! Stay there ! For a little — oh , not for long ! But for a month , say , after [[your]112-james stuart Princess]3700-your princess comes triumphing into [Bologna]1-bologna . Promise [me]164-maria vittoria that ! No , [I]164-maria vittoria will not have it ! [I]164-maria vittoria can see [her]3700-your princess proud cursed face a - flush . No ! [You]112-james stuart think too much of what [she]3700-your princess has suffered . If [I]164-maria vittoria could have suffered too ! But suffering , shame , humiliation , these fall to [women]3284-women , always have fallen . [We]3702-we have learnt to bear [them]3284-women so that [we]3702-we feel [them]3284-women less than [you]112-james stuart . [[My]164-maria vittoria dear lord]3703-my dear lord , believe [me]164-maria vittoria ! [Her]3700-your princess suffering is no great thing . If [we]3702-we love [we]3702-we welcome it ! Each throb of pain endured for love becomes a thrill of joy . If [I]164-maria vittoria could have suffered too ! "[164-maria vittoria] It was strange to hear [this girl with the streaming eyes and tormented face]1362-this girl with the streaming eyes and tormented face bewail [her]1362-this girl with the streaming eyes and tormented face fate in that [she]1362-this girl with the streaming eyes and tormented face had not won that great privilege of suffering . "[111-whittington] [The Chevalier]348-the chevalier was satisfied with the reply . [He]348-the chevalier had chosen the right attendant for this nocturnal visit . " [The King]3089-the king will receive [you]142-gaydon now , "[121-edgar] said [he]121-edgar . " Let [us]3730-us go . "[121-edgar] " It is broad daylight . [We]3730-us shall be seen . "[348-the chevalier] " Not if [the street]292-the street is empty , "[121-edgar] said [Edgar]121-edgar , looking out of the window . [Edgar]121-edgar walked forward to the end of [the passage]497-the passage with [Gaydon]142-gaydon at [his]121-edgar heels . [The two men]462-the two men came to a flight of stone steps , which [they]462-the two men descended . [The steps]1392-the steps led to [a dark and dripping cellar with no pavement but the mud]1393-a dark and dripping cellar with no pavement but the mud , and that depressed into puddles . The air was cold and noisome ; the walls to the touch of [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's hand were greasy with slime . [He]142-gaydon followed [Edgar]121-edgar across [the cellar]3184-the cellar into [a sort of tunnel]1395-a sort of tunnel . [Here]3086-here [Edgar]121-edgar drew an end of candle from [his]121-edgar pocket and lighted it . [The tunnel]1397-the tunnel was so low that [Gaydon]142-gaydon , though [a shortish man]1398-a shortish man , could barely hold [his]142-gaydon head erect . [He]142-gaydon followed [Edgar]121-edgar to the end and up [a flight of winding steps]1399-a flight of winding steps . The air grew warmer and dryer . They had risen above ground , the spiral wound within the thickness of a wall . [The steps]1392-the steps ended abruptly ; there was no door visible ; in face of [them]1392-the steps and on each side the bare stone walls enclosed [them]1392-the steps . " [You]142-gaydon will breathe no word of this passage , [Major Gaydon]142-gaydon , "[121-edgar] said [he]121-edgar . " [The house]3196-the house was built a century ago when [Rome]4-rome was more troubled than it is to - day , but [the passage]497-the passage was never more useful than now . [Men from [England]19-england , whose names it would astonish [you]142-gaydon to know]3734-men from england , whose names it would astonish you to know , have trodden these steps on a secret visit to [the King]3089-the king . Ah ! "[121-edgar] From the wall before [their]1392-the steps faces a great slab of the size of a door sank noiselessly down and disclosed a wooden panel . The panel slid aside . [Edgar]121-edgar and [Gaydon]142-gaydon stepped into a little cabinet lighted by a single window . [The room]317-the room was empty . [Gaydon]142-gaydon took a peep out of the window and saw the Tiber eddying beneath . [Edgar]121-edgar went to a corner and touched a spring . The stone slab rose from its grooves ; the panel slid back across it ; at the same moment the door of [the room]317-the room was opened , and [the Chevalier]348-the chevalier stepped across the threshold . [Gaydon]142-gaydon could no longer even pretend to doubt who had walked with [Whittington]111-whittington to [the Caprara Palace]1341-the caprara palace the night before . It was none of [his]142-gaydon business , however , [he]142-gaydon assured [himself]142-gaydon . If [[his]142-gaydon King]326-his king dwelt with emphasis upon the dangers of the enterprise , it was not [his]142-gaydon business to remark upon it or to be thereby disheartened . [The King]3089-the king said very graciously that [he]3089-the king would hold [the major]1407-the major and [[his]1407-the major friends]989-his friends in no less esteem if by any misfortune [they]1409-they came back empty - handed . That was most kind of [him]3089-the king , but it was none of [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's business . [The King]3089-the king was ill at ease and looked as though [he]3089-the king had not slept a wink the livelong night . Well , swollen eyes and a patched pallid face disfigure [all men]1411-all men at times , and in any case [they]1409-they were none of [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's business . [He]142-gaydon rode out of [Rome]4-rome that afternoon as the light was failing . [He]142-gaydon rode at a quick trot , and did not notice at the corner of [a street]282-a street [a big stalwart man who sauntered along swinging [his]1413-a big stalwart man who sauntered along swinging his stick by the tassel with a vacant look of idleness upon the passers - by stick by the tassel with a vacant look of idleness upon [the passers - by]1414-the passers - by]1413-a big stalwart man who sauntered along swinging his stick by the tassel with a vacant look of idleness upon the passers - by . [He]142-gaydon stopped and directed the same vacant look at [Gaydon]142-gaydon . But [he]142-gaydon was thinking curiously , " Will [he]126-wogan tell [Charles Wogan]126-wogan ? "[142-gaydon] [The stalwart man]1415-the stalwart man was [Harry Whittington]111-whittington . [Gaydon]142-gaydon , however , never breathed a word about [the Caprara Palace]1341-the caprara palace when [he]142-gaydon handed the passport to [Charles Wogan]126-wogan at [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt . [Wogan]126-wogan was sitting propped up with pillows in a chair , and [he]126-wogan asked [Gaydon]142-gaydon many questions of the news at [Rome]4-rome , and how [the King]3089-the king bore [himself]3089-the king . " [The King]3089-the king was not in the best of spirits , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon . " With this , "[126-wogan] cried [Wogan]126-wogan , flourishing the passport , " [we]3737-we 'll find a means to hearten [him]3089-the king . "[126-wogan] [Gaydon]142-gaydon filled a pipe and lighted it . " Will [you]126-wogan tell [me]142-gaydon , [Wogan]126-wogan , "[142-gaydon] [he]142-gaydon asked,—"I am by nature curious,—was it [the King]3089-the king who proposed this enterprise to [you]126-wogan , or was it [you]126-wogan who proposed it to [the King]3089-the king ? "[126-wogan] The question had an extraordinary effect . [Wogan]126-wogan was startled out of [his]126-wogan chair . " What do [you]142-gaydon mean ? "[126-wogan] [he]126-wogan exclaimed fiercely . There was something more than fierceness in the words,—an accent of fear , it almost seemed to [Gaydon]142-gaydon . There was a look almost of fear in [his]126-wogan eyes , as though [he]126-wogan had let some appalling secret slip . [Gaydon]142-gaydon stared at [him]142-gaydon in wonder , and [Wogan]126-wogan recovered [himself]126-wogan with a laugh . " [Faith]162-faith , "[126-wogan] said [he]126-wogan , " it is a question to perplex [a man]235-a man . [I]126-wogan misdoubt but [we]3741-we both had the thought about the same time . ' [Wogan]126-wogan , ' said [he]126-wogan , ' there 's [the Princess]3107-the princess with a chain on [her]3107-the princess leg , so to speak , ' and [I]126-wogan answered [him]126-wogan , ' A chain 's a galling sort of thing to [a lady]3124-a lady 's ankle . ' There was little more said if [I]126-wogan remember right . "[126-wogan] [Gaydon]142-gaydon nodded as though [his]142-gaydon curiosity was now satisfied . [Wogan]126-wogan 's alarm was strange , no doubt , strange and unexpected like the [Chevalier]114-the chevalier 's visit to [the Caprara Palace]1341-the caprara palace . [Gaydon]142-gaydon had a glimpse of [dark and troubled waters]1419-dark and troubled waters , but [he]142-gaydon turned [his]142-gaydon face away . [They]1420-they were none of [his]142-gaydon business . In an hour , however , [he]142-gaydon returned out of breath and with a face white from despair . [Wogan]126-wogan was still writing at [his]126-wogan table , but at [his]126-wogan first glance towards [Gaydon]142-gaydon [he]126-wogan started quickly to [his]126-wogan feet , and altogether forgot to cover over [his]126-wogan sheet of paper . [He]126-wogan carefully shut the door . " [You]142-gaydon have bad news , "[126-wogan] said [he]126-wogan . " There was never worse , "[142-gaydon] answered [Gaydon]142-gaydon . [He]142-gaydon had run so fast , [he]142-gaydon was so discomposed , that [he]142-gaydon could with difficulty speak . But [he]142-gaydon gasped [his]142-gaydon bad news out in the end . " [I]142-gaydon went to [[my]142-gaydon brother]3272-my brother major to report [my]142-gaydon return . [He]3272-my brother was entertaining [[his]3272-my brother friends]989-his friends . [He]3272-my brother had a letter this morning from [Strasbourg]32-strasbourg and [he]3272-my brother read it aloud . The letter said a rumour was running through [the town]3115-the town that [the Chevalier Wogan]167-wogan had already rescued [the Princess]3107-the princess and was being hotly pursued on [the road to [Trent]52-trent]3748-the road to trent . "[142-gaydon] If [Wogan]167-wogan felt any disquietude [he]167-wogan was careful to hide it . [He]167-wogan sat comfortably down upon the sofa . " [I]167-wogan expected rumour would be busy with [us]3749-us , "[167-wogan] said [he]167-wogan , " but never that it would take so favourable a shape . "[167-wogan] " Favourable ! "[142-gaydon] exclaimed [Gaydon]142-gaydon . " To be sure , for its falsity will be established to - morrow , and ridicule cast upon [those who spread and believed it]3750-those who spread and believed it . False alarms are the proper strategy to conceal the real assault . The rumour does [us]3749-us a service . [Our]3749-us secret is very well kept , for here am [I]142-gaydon in [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt , and [people living in [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt]3751-people living in schlestadt believe [me]142-gaydon on [the road to [Trent]52-trent]3748-the road to trent . [I]142-gaydon will go back with [you]142-gaydon to [the major]1407-the major 's and have a laugh at [[his]1407-the major correspondent]3754-his correspondent . Courage , [[my]142-gaydon friend]3085-my friend . [We]3749-us will give [[our]3749-us enemies]3756-our enemies a month . Let [them]3756-our enemies cry wolf as often as [they]3756-our enemies will during that month , [we]3749-us 'll get into the fold all the more easily in the end . "[142-gaydon] [Wogan]167-wogan took [his]167-wogan hat to accompany [Gaydon]142-gaydon , but at that moment [he]167-wogan heard [another man stumbling in a great haste up the stairs]1421-another man stumbling in a great haste up the stairs . [Misset]143-misset broke into [the room]317-the room with a face as discomposed as [Gaydon]142-gaydon 's had been . " Here 's [another who has heard the same rumour]3757-another who has heard the same rumour , "[167-wogan] said [Wogan]167-wogan . " It is more than a rumour , "[143-misset] said [Misset]143-misset . " It is an order , and most peremptory , from [the Court of [France]54-france]53-the court of france , forbidding [any officer of [Dillon]144-dillon 's regiment]3758-any officer of dillon 's regiment to be absent for more than twenty - four hours from [his]167-wogan duties on pain of being broke . [Our]3759-we secret 's out . That 's the plain truth of the matter . "[167-wogan] [He]167-wogan stood by the table drumming with [his]167-wogan fingers in a great agitation . Then [his]167-wogan fingers stopped . [He]167-wogan had been drumming upon [Wogan]167-wogan 's sheet of paper , and the writing on the sheet had suddenly attracted [his]167-wogan notice . It was writing in unusually regular lines . [Gaydon]142-gaydon , arrested by [Misset]143-misset 's change from restlessness to fixity , looked that way for a second , too , but [he]142-gaydon turned [his]142-gaydon head aside very quickly . [Wogan]167-wogan 's handwriting was none of [his]142-gaydon business . " [We]3759-we will give [them]3760-them a month , "[167-wogan] said [Wogan]167-wogan , who was conjecturing at the motive of this order from [the Court of [France]54-france]53-the court of france . " No doubt [we]3759-we are suspected . [I]167-wogan never had a hope that [we]3759-we should not be . [The Court of [France]54-france]53-the court of france , [you]3761-you see , can do no less than forbid [us]3759-we , but [I]167-wogan should not be surprised if it winks at [us]3759-we on the sly . [We]3759-we will give [them]3760-them a month . [Colonel Lally]168-colonel lally is [a friend of [mine]167-wogan]3762-a friend of mine and [a friend of [the King]3089-the king]3763-a friend of the king . [We]3759-we will get an abatement of that order , so that not one of [you]3761-you shall be cashiered . "[167-wogan] " [I]143-misset do n't flinch at that , "[143-misset] said [Misset]143-misset , " but the secret 's out . "[143-misset] " Then [we]3759-we must use the more precautions , "[167-wogan] said [Wogan]167-wogan . [He]167-wogan had no doubt whatever that somehow [he]167-wogan would bring [the Princess]3107-the princess safely out of [[her]3107-the princess prison]1424-her prison to [Bologna]1-bologna . It could not be that [she]3107-the princess was born to be wasted . [Misset]143-misset , however , was not so confident upon the matter . " [A strange , imperturbable man]3765-a strange , imperturbable man is [Charles Wogan]126-wogan , "[167-wogan] said [he]167-wogan to [Gaydon]142-gaydon and [O'Toole]158-o'toole the same evening . " Did [you]3761-you happen by any chance to cast [your]3761-you eye over the paper [I]167-wogan had [my]167-wogan hand on ? "[167-wogan] " [I]142-gaydon did not , "[142-gaydon] said [Gaydon]142-gaydon , in a great hurry . " It was a private letter , no doubt . "[142-gaydon] " It was poetry . There 's no need for [you]142-gaydon to hurry , [[my]142-gaydon friend]3085-my friend . It was more than mere poetry , it was in Latin . [I]142-gaydon read the first line on the page , and it ran , ' Te , dum spernit , arat novus accola ; max ubi cultam — ' "[142-gaydon] [Gaydon]142-gaydon tore [his]142-gaydon arm away from [Misset]143-misset . " [I]142-gaydon 'll hear no more of it , "[142-gaydon] [he]142-gaydon cried . " Poetry is none of [my]142-gaydon business . "[142-gaydon] " There , [Dick]169-dick , [you]169-dick are wrong , "[158-o'toole] said [O'Toole]158-o'toole , sententiously . Both [Misset]143-misset and [Gaydon]142-gaydon came to a dead stop and stared . Never had poetry so strange an advocate . [O'Toole]158-o'toole set [his]158-o'toole great legs apart and [his]158-o'toole arms akimbo . [He]158-o'toole rocked [himself]158-o'toole backwards and forwards on [his]158-o'toole heels and toes , while a benevolent smile of superiority wrinkled across [his]158-o'toole broad face from ear to ear . " Yes , [I]158-o'toole 've done it , "[158-o'toole] said [he]158-o'toole ; " [I]158-o'toole 've written poetry . It is a thing [a polite gentleman]3767-a polite gentleman should be able to do . So [I]158-o'toole did it . It was n't in Latin , because [the young lady]3768-the young lady it was written to did n't understand Latin . [Her]3768-the young lady name was [Lucy]170-lucy , and [I]158-o'toole rhymed [her]3768-the young lady to ' juicy , ' and the pleasure of it made [her]3768-the young lady purple in the face . There were to have been four lines , but there were never more than three and a half because [I]158-o'toole could not think of a suitable rhyme to O'Toole . [Lucy]170-lucy said [she]170-lucy knew one , but [she]170-lucy would never tell it [me]158-o'toole . "[158-o'toole] [Wogan]126-wogan 's poetry , however , was of quite a different kind , and had [Gaydon]142-gaydon looked at it a trifle more closely , [he]158-o'toole would have experienced some relief . It was all about the sorrows and miseries of [his]126-wogan unfortunate race and the cruel oppression of [England]19-england . [England]19-england owed [all [its]19-england great men]1425-all its great men to [Ireland]30-ireland and was currish enough never to acknowledge the debt . [Wogan]126-wogan always grew melancholy and grave - faced on that subject when [he]126-wogan had the leisure to be idle . [He]126-wogan thought bitterly of [the many Irish officers sent into exile and killed in the service of [alien countries]1427-alien countries]1426-the many irish officers sent into exile and killed in the service of alien countries ; [his]126-wogan sense of injustice grew into a passionate sort of despair , and the despair tumbled out of [him]126-wogan in sonorous Latin verse written in the Virgilian measure . [He]126-wogan wrote a deal of it during this month of waiting , and a long while afterwards sent an extract to [Dr. Swift]171-dr. swift and received [the great man]1428-the great man 's compliments upon [its]1429-its felicity , as [anyone]322-anyone may see for [himself]322-anyone in [the doctor]1235-the doctor 's correspondence . How the month passed for [James Stuart]112-james stuart in [Rome]4-rome may be partly guessed from a letter which was brought to [Wogan]126-wogan by [Michael Vezozzi]172-michael vezozzi , [[the Chevalier]348-the chevalier 's body - servant]1433-the chevalier 's body - servant . The letter announced that [King George of [England]19-england]173-king george of england had offered [the Princess Clementina]116-clementina a dowry of £ 100,000 if [she]116-clementina would marry [the Prince of Baden]1434-the prince of baden , and that [the Prince of [Baden]55-baden with a numerous following]174-the prince of baden with a numerous following was already at [Innspruck]17-innspruck to prosecute [his]173-king george of england suit . " [I]126-wogan do not know but what [[her]116-clementina Highness]3138-her highness , "[126-wogan] [he]126-wogan wrote , " will receive the best consolation for [her]116-clementina sufferings on [my]126-wogan account if [she]116-clementina accepts so favourable a proposal , rather than run so many hazards as [she]116-clementina must needs do as [[my]126-wogan wife]3598-my wife . For [myself]126-wogan , [I]126-wogan have been summoned most urgently into [Spain]18-spain and am travelling thither on the instant . "[126-wogan] [Wogan]126-wogan could make neither head nor tail of the letter . Why should [the King]3089-the king go to [Spain]18-spain at the time when [the Princess Clementina]1436-the princess clementina might be expected at [Bologna]1-bologna ? It was plain that [he]3089-the king did not expect [Wogan]126-wogan would succeed . [He]126-wogan was disheartened . [Wogan]126-wogan came to the conclusion that there was the whole meaning of the letter . [He]126-wogan was , however , for other reasons glad to receive it . " It is very well [I]126-wogan have this letter , "[126-wogan] said [he]126-wogan , " for until it came [I]126-wogan had no scrap of writing whatever to show either to [[her]1436-the princess clementina Highness]3138-her highness or , what [I]126-wogan take to be more important , to [[her]1436-the princess clementina Highness 's mother]3772-her highness 's mother , "[126-wogan] and [he]126-wogan went back to [his]126-wogan poetry . [Misset]143-misset and [[his]3089-the king wife]589-his wife , on the other hand , drove forward to [the town of Colmar]1438-the town of colmar , where [they]1439-they bought [a travelling carriage]232-a travelling carriage and the necessaries for the journey . [Misset]143-misset left [[his]3089-the king wife]589-his wife at [Colmar]56-colmar , but returned every twenty - four hours [himself]3089-the king . [They]1439-they made the excuse that [Misset]143-misset had won a deal of money at play and was minded to lay it out in presents to [[his]3089-the king wife]589-his wife . [The stratagem]1443-the stratagem had a wonderful success at [Schlestadt]31-schlestadt , especially amongst [the ladies]604-the ladies , who could do nothing day and night but praise in [[their]604-the ladies husbands]1445-their husbands ' hearing so excellent a mode of disposing of one 's winnings . [O'Toole]158-o'toole spent [his]158-o'toole month in polishing [his]158-o'toole pistols and sharpening [his]158-o'toole sword . It is true that [he]158-o'toole had to persuade [Jenny]161-jenny to bear [them]1439-they company , but that was the work of an afternoon . [He]158-o'toole told [her]161-jenny the story of [the rich Austrian heiress]1446-the rich austrian heiress , promised [her]161-jenny a hundred guineas and a damask gown , gave [her]161-jenny a kiss , and the matter was settled . [Jenny]161-jenny passed [her]161-jenny month in a delicious excitement . [She]161-jenny was [a daughter of the camp]1447-a daughter of the camp , and had no fears whatever . [She]161-jenny was [a conspirator]1448-a conspirator ; [she]161-jenny was trusted with a tremendous secret ; [she]161-jenny was to help [the beautiful and enormous O'Toole]1449-the beautiful and enormous o'toole to [a rich and beautiful wife]1450-a rich and beautiful wife ; [she]161-jenny was to outwit [an old curmudgeon of [an uncle]1452-an uncle]1451-an old curmudgeon of an uncle ; [she]161-jenny was to succour [a maiden heart - broken and imprisoned]1453-a maiden heart - broken and imprisoned . [Jenny]161-jenny was quite uplifted . Never had [a maid - servant]1454-a maid - servant been born to so high a destiny . [Her]161-jenny only difficulty was to keep silence , and when the silence became no longer endurable [she]161-jenny would run on some excuse or another to [Wogan]126-wogan and divert [him]126-wogan with the properest sentiments . " To [me]161-jenny , "[161-jenny] [she]161-jenny would cry , " there 's nothing sinful in changing clothes with [the beautiful mistress of O'Toole]3773-the beautiful mistress of o'toole . [Christian charity]175-christian charity says [we]3774-we are to make [others]460-others happy . [I]161-jenny am [a Christian]3776-a christian , and as to [the uncle]3777-the uncle [he]3777-the uncle can go to the devil ! [He]3777-the uncle can do nothing to [me]161-jenny but talk , and [I]161-jenny do n't understand [his]3777-the uncle stupid language . "[161-jenny] [Jenny]161-jenny was [the one person]1455-the one person really happy during this month . It was [Wogan]126-wogan 's effort to keep [her]161-jenny so , for [she]161-jenny was the very pivot of [his]126-wogan plan . There remains yet [one other who had most reason of all to repine at the delay]1456-one other who had most reason of all to repine at the delay , [the Princess [Clementina]116-clementina]1436-the princess clementina . [[Her]116-clementina mother]3108-her mother wearied [her]116-clementina with perpetual complaints , [the Prince of [Baden]55-baden , who was allowed admittance to [the villa]526-the villa]1459-the prince of baden , who was allowed admittance to the villa , persecuted [her]116-clementina with [his]1459-the prince of baden , who was allowed admittance to the villa attentions ; [she]116-clementina knew nothing of what was planned for [her]116-clementina escape , and the rigorous confinement was not relaxed . It was not a happy time for [Clementina]116-clementina . Yet [she]116-clementina was not entirely unhappy . A thought had come to [her]116-clementina and stayed with [her]116-clementina which called the colour to [her]116-clementina cheeks and a smile to [her]116-clementina lips . It accounted to [her]116-clementina for the delay ; [her]116-clementina pride was restored by it ; because of it [she]116-clementina became yet more patient with [[her]116-clementina mother]3108-her mother , more gentle with [the Prince of [Baden]55-baden]1434-the prince of baden , more good - humoured to [[her]116-clementina gaolers]1463-her gaolers . It sang at [her]116-clementina heart like a bird ; it lightened in [her]116-clementina grey eyes . It had come to [her]116-clementina one sleepless night , and the morning had not revealed it as a mere phantasy born of the night . The more [she]116-clementina pondered it , the more certain was [she]116-clementina of its truth . [[Her]116-clementina King]1375-her king was coming [himself]1375-her king at the hazard of [his]1375-her king life to rescue [her]116-clementina . Therefore [she]116-clementina waited in patience . It was still winter at [Innspruck]17-innspruck , though the calendar declared it to be spring . April was budless and cold , a month of storms ; the snow drifted deep along [the streets]399-the streets and [M. Chateaudoux]125-chateaudoux was much inconvenienced during [his]125-chateaudoux promenades in the afternoon . [He]125-chateaudoux would come back with most reproachful eyes for [Clementina]116-clementina in that [she]116-clementina so stubbornly clung to [her]116-clementina vagabond exile and refused so fine a match as [the Prince of [Baden]55-baden]1434-the prince of baden . On the afternoon of the 25th , however , [Clementina]116-clementina read more than reproach in [his]125-chateaudoux eyes , more than discomfort in the agitation of [his]125-chateaudoux manner . [The little chamberlain]1467-the little chamberlain was afraid . [Clementina]116-clementina guessed the reason of [his]125-chateaudoux fear . " [He]125-chateaudoux has come ! "[116-clementina] [she]116-clementina cried . [She]116-clementina was like an ember blown to a flame . " [You]116-clementina were stopped in [your]116-clementina walk . [You]116-clementina have a message for [me]116-clementina . "[116-clementina] suddenly exclaimed [Clementina]116-clementina . " On the evening of the 27th , "[588-the prince] said [the Prince]588-the prince . [Clementina]116-clementina laughed softly in a way which [he]588-the prince did not understand . [She]116-clementina was altogether in a strange , incomprehensible mood that afternoon , and when [he]588-the prince learnt next day that [she]116-clementina had taken to [her]116-clementina bed [he]588-the prince was not surprised . At [the second posting stage]1499-the second posting stage , which [he]588-the prince reached about three of the afternoon , [he]588-the prince crossed [a hired carriage]1500-a hired carriage on [its]1500-a hired carriage way to [Innspruck]17-innspruck . [He]588-the prince noticed the great size of [the coachman on the box]1505-the coachman on the box , [he]588-the prince saw also that [a man]235-a man and [two women]1507-two women were seated within [the carriage]287-the carriage , and that [a servant]1509-a servant rode on horseback by the door . [The road]228-the road , however , was a busy one ; day and [night travellers]1511-night travellers passed up and down ; [the Prince]588-the prince gave only a passing scrutiny to [that carriage]1513-that carriage rolling down [the hill]1514-the hill to [Innspruck]17-innspruck . Besides , [he]588-the prince was acquainted neither with [Gaydon]142-gaydon , who rode within [the carriage]287-the carriage , nor with [Wogan]126-wogan , [the servant at the door]1516-the servant at the door , nor with [O'Toole]158-o'toole , [the fat man on the box]1517-the fat man on the box . At nightfall [the Prince]174-the prince of baden with a numerous following came to [Nazareth]57-nazareth , [a lonely village amongst [the mountains]1519-the mountains with [a single tavern , where [he]174-the prince of baden with a numerous following thought to sleep the night]1520-a single tavern , where he thought to sleep the night .
